A law of composition on a set $M$ is said to be associative if $(ab)c = a(bc)$ for all elements $a, b, c \in M$.
The order of a group $G$, denoted as ord $G$, is defined as the number of elements in $G$ if $G$ is finite. If $G$ is infinite, its order is said to be infinite.

Given a commutative ring R, the polynomial ring R[X] is the set of all sequences (a_i) where a_i in R and a_i=0 for almost all i, equipped with addition and multiplication defined by (a_i)+(b_i)=(a_i+b_i) and (a_i) 
cdot (b_i)=(c_i) where c_i=
sum_{
u+
u=i} a_
u b_
u. Elements of R[X] can be written as 
sum_{i=0}^n a_i X^i where X is the sequence (0,1,0,0,...).
For an element $a \in R$, the principal ideal generated by $a$ is $R a:=\{r a ; r \in R\}$. It is the smallest ideal in $R$ containing $a$.
Let $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ be a ring homomorphism. The image of $\varphi$, denoted $\operatorname{im} \varphi$, is defined as $\varphi(R)$, which is a subring of $R'$.
Homomorphisms between A-modules, also referred to as A-homomorphisms, are defined just as in the context of vector spaces.
An element x of an A-module M is called a torsion element if there exists an element a in A-{0} such that a.x = 0.
A field extension $K \subset L$ is called finitely generated if there exist finitely many elements $\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n} \in L$ such that $L=K(\alpha_{1}, \ldots, \alpha_{n})$.
An algebraic field extension $L / K$ is trivial if every element of $L$ is algebraic over $K$.
An extension $L / K$ is called separable if it does not contain any inseparable algebraic elements over $K$.

A subgroup H of a finite group G is called a p-Sylow subgroup if H is a p-group such that p does not divide the index (G: H). This means there exist integers k, m in N satisfying ord H=p^k, as well as ord G=p^k m, where p does not divide m.

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A trivial algebraic field extension (ID: 8) is a specialization of a finitely generated field extension (ID: 7) because every trivial algebraic field extension, by definition, involves a finite number of algebraic elements over the base field, thus making it finitely generated.
